text:
<@UBF9YRB6H> if you just want to cite a few references for something like a blog post, then you can use hyperreferences like I use here for instance: <https://tlienart.github.io/pub/csml/cvxopt/pgd.html#additional_references> (Note the reference in the last paragraph).

What <@UPJ6Q2SQY> has worked on is to manage a file in YAML which has all his bibliographical entries iiuc (see also his package <https://github.com/kellertuer/FranklinLiszt.jl>)

If what you're hoping for is something that can ingest a `biblatex` file then this is not supported (this is a separate project by itself, see <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/state-of-the-literature-references/51807>)

Finally I'm not too sure about what pandoc generates there, maybe what you could do is get pandoc to generate HTML directly and then input that within
```~~~
raw html
~~~```
(apologies for my answers going in all directions, I'm not exactly sure what you're hoping for; feel free to open an issue for a more detailed discussion)

attachments.text: I recently ran into the idea of using some references within my doc strings and within the documentation.
